description:
Excellence in applied research and development for manufacturing companies – this is what the Fraunhofer Institute for Production Systems und Design Technology IPK in Berlin has stood for over 35 years. What does that mean? We support companies with innovation, from product development to the production process, maintenance of capital goods and recycling of products to the design and management of factory operations.

description:
Your mission:

The lack of publicly available data, the cost intensity, and the high time expenditure associated with acquiring labeled data are leading to the increasing use of synthetic data when training deep neural networks for diverse computer vison tasks (e.g., drone detection). Data generation methods range from fairly simple techniques, such as domain randomization, to game engine-based simulations in three-dimensional environments (e.g., via Unreal Engine). Despite their popularity, the discrepancy between simulation and reality (also known as simulation-reality gap) is a non-negligible and controversial issue of ongoing research. Therefore, the development of generation techniques for synthetic data, as well as the evaluation and quantification of their benefits and limitations are important research topics.

The objective of this work is the analysis of the applicability of synthetic data for deep learing-based object detection derived from a three-dimensional replica of the target environment (especially regarding the simulation-reality gap). This includes

the game engine-based simulation and generation of synthetic data including the enhancement of the 3D model of the target domain (e.g., with respect to vegetation, lightning, weather conditions, or seasonal effects)
the investigation of the existence and extent of the simulation-reality gap using state-of-the-art object detection models including different training strategies
the adaption of simulation parameters to complete real data in the most efficient way.

This work is based on existing preliminary work, upon which further aspects will be explored.

Your qualifications:

currently enrolled as a Master student in computer science, mathematics, optical engineering or similar major
experience in working with Unreal or Unity (or something comparable), ideally experience with Microsoft AirSim
interest in deep learning, image processing, and object detection
basic Python skills (ideally with respect to deep learning applications, e.g., Pytorch or Tensorflow)
knowledge of the German language is perferred though not necessary

description:
Your mission:

Free-Space Optical (FSO) communication enables ultra-high-rate data transmission and is an enabling technology for long distance Quantum Key Distribution (QKD). FSO communication systems, on the other hand, are complex technologies that include a number of subsystems that must all function in unison. Therefore, determining the quality of the link that can be established in a particular communication context is a challenging task in and of itself. The classical data rate in a conventional communication scenario or the secure key rate of a QKD protocol can be determined using the predicted signal intensity (i.e., the link budget). Creating software to calculate overall transmissivity and, consequently, the signal strength seen at the receiver, will be the task at hand. This software will be instrumental for the design of FSO communication systems at DLR.

student specializing in computer science, information technology, electronic engineering or physics
very good programming skills, including scripting languages (Matlab, Python, or comparable languages) and GUI design
knowledge of Git and Github/Gitlab
very good knowledge of English
